Award.AwardTitle: Autonomous, Low Cost Platform for Seafloor Geodesy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs request funding to develop a cost effective approach for accurately measuring short-term vertical motions of the seafloor, maintaining a continuous long-term record of seafloor pressure without the requirement for costly ship time. This capability will be developed by equipping a University of Hawaii Wave Glider with an integrated acoustic telemetry package, a dual frequency geodetic-grade Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, meteorological sensors, an onboard embedded processing unit, and cellular telemetry. They will demonstrate the use of the Wave Glider to interrogate high accuracy pressure sensors on the sea floor to retrieve pressure and temperature data, and transmit the seafloor data along with high rate GPS observables and meteorological data to shore. They will then integrate the seafloor measurements with surface air pressure data, and precise vertical measurements of the sea surface from kinematic positioning of the Wave Glider?s GPS to determine cm-scale accuracy vertical seafloor motions.

Broader Impacts:

The ability to make real-time measurements of seafloor motions has the potential to dramatically enhance prediction of marine geo-hazards. Further, if these glider systems can eventually be adapted for GPS-A systems (i.e., measurement of horizontal as well as vertical motions) it will revolutionize our understanding of seafloor deformation. This proposed project has the potential to create a platform that would be capable of investigating scientific questions related to tsunamigenic hazards in offshore regions of subduction zones and unstable volcano flanks. These questions are of great importance to society as many millions of people are currently vulnerable to tsunami impacts. The addition of a low-cost, non-ship based resource for collection seafloor geodetic data would be extremely beneficial to the scientific community. It will also provide funding for a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Measurements of land-surface motions provide crucial insights into many important processes occuring below the surface. Globally, many of these processes occur underwater. Mega thrust faults at subduction zones, submarine landslides and oceanic volcanoes may generate deformation signals that give key insights into these processes. Timely receipt of observations of these motions is important for making an informed response to events and the hazards they may present. The high cost of acquiring geodetic data underwater, however, means that motions of the sea floor remain largely unobserved. We have developed a Wave Glider-based system that offers a cost effective approach for accurately measuring short-term vertical motions of the seafloor, and the ability to maintain a continuous long-term record of seafloor pressure with near real-time data transfer, without the requirement for costly ship time.

We have built a sea-floor geodesy payload for our Wave Glider that enables it to communicate with our sea-floor instrument. This instrument records precise pressures and can host other ancillary instruments. Any vertical motion of the sea-floor will change the observed pressure. Changes in the sea surface height, as well the sea surface atmospheric pressure, also contribute to observed changes in sea-floor pressure. In order to control for these factors we also equipped our Wave Glider with a precise GPS system and a barometer. In this way the Wave Glider itself functions as part of the geodetic observing system. Our results, based on measurements made in the complex submarine pressure environment in Hawaii, indicate that we should expect to be able to detect centimeter-scale vertical motions.

We expect our project to inspire a rapidly expanding number of sea-floor geodetic projects to monitor and study many of the important structures and the processes that occur in the marine environment. These studies will lead to bettter understanding and assessment of the hazards facing our coastal communities, and inform our efforts to mitigate them.
